issue.title: Update Valgrind suppression files for recent implementation changes
issue.body:
<!-- Please give a brief explanation of the purpose of this pull request. -->
Updating the Valgrind suppression files to deal with the following recent changes:
- NTRU Prime code changed slightly so line offset has to change.
- BIKE variants changed names.

comment.body:
I've run the `constant-time-x64` CircleCI job locally which does constant-time testing on the generic implementation and it passes.  Currently locally running (probably will take all night) the `constant-time-x64-extensions` job which does constant-time testing when configured with `OQS_OPT_TARGET=auto`. Will report on results once it's done. 

Note that the `constant-time-x64-extensions` job won't compile unless #1067 is applied, but we can merge these two PRs independently since that CI job is actually commented out and only ever run manually (at least for now).

issue.title: automate setting security/NIST levels in generate.py using liboqs input
issue.body:
Fixes #315 

This new logic could also be used to completely do away with fields "[bits_]security" in `generate.yml` (as it can deduce them from `liboqs`' `claimed_nist_level`. What'd you think @dstebila @xvzcf ?

comment.body:
> reading the NIST levels from the liboqs algorithm datasheets.

Agreed, it does. However, this does not ascertain that the NIST levels in `liboqs` and `oqs-openssl` do match, as the former are not read from the datasheets. Hence, this code does not fix #315. It would, of course, if similar NIST level "doc->src ascertainment" would be added to `liboqs`: Is that your intention?

issue.title: Use Github Actions for some CI
issue.body:
<!-- Please give a brief explanation of the purpose of this pull request. -->
In hopes of partially alleviating pressure on our CircleCI quota as per #1025, this PR switches some jobs to use Github Actions rather than CircleCI.  In particular, I've started off with more "standalone" type jobs, which include:
- alpine (2 jobs - with OpenSSL and without)
- address sanitizer (1 job) (currently disabled until #1067 lands)
- ARM emulation jobs (1 job - armhf)

Nothing stops us from moving other jobs over as well, such as the main Ubuntu x86_64 and i386 jobs, or the macOS jobs, or even the Windows jobs.  But I wanted to get initial feedback and discussion of strategy.  This currently doesn't affect triggering of downstream jobs (when a merge to main happens) or Travis/Appveyor (except for filtering branches of the form `ghactionsonly-*` from being run on those other CI platforms, allowing us to test just this one CI system).

Although the build shows as red, if the only failure is CircleCI, then that's due to there being no jobs that are meant to be run on CircleCI due to the `ghactionsonly-*` filtering currently going on.  That problem should not be present on other branches.

comment.body:
Thanks @dstebila for setting this up/giving this a try! This seems to be a reasonable way out of our (C)CI timing problems -- assuming GHActions doesn't impose similar limitations once more tests are running there at the same time: Does anyone know about that -- short of trying it by moving over all jobs? 

Judging from the code and run logs, the approach looks good to me: Same baseline containers, very similar test code, better runtime.

On the negative side, this adds to our CI "zoo". Or is the idea to move _everything_ over to GHActions? If so (my personal preference to not deal with different CI system's quirks), I'd think we'd need to add `ssh(d)` support to our CI containers and do something similar to [this](https://github.com/marketplace?category=testing&type=actions&query=ssh+) to enable SSH access to debug problems with CI.

issue.title: Graceful runtime CPU feature handling

labels.name: future-work
labels.description: Will not be fixed in current release cycle

issue.body:
Ensure all code is designed such that it can not only be configured at compile time to deal with different CPU feature sets (e.g., presence/absence of AVX2) but also handle those gracefully at runtime, e.g, by automatically falling back to a non-optimised version of the same functionality.

In other words, all code compiled with, e.g., `-mavx2` should also run without error on CPUs that do *not* have support for all features (AVX2 in this example).

To help with this, we will integrate the [CPU features](https://github.com/google/cpu_features) library and for starters will add warnings if the library is running on a CPU with a feature set different from the one encountered during build (reducing the surprise when one encounters an `illegal instruction exception` during execution until this issue is fully addressed :-)

Edited by @dstebila to add:

- [X] Use cpu\_features instead of \_\_builtin\_cpu
- [X] Update copy-from-pqclean schemes to do runtime detection
- [x] Runtime detection for SHA-3 ~using  [XKCP](https://github.com/XKCP/XKCP)~
- [X] Runtime detection for Frodo (#878)
- [ ] Runtime detection for SIKE
- [x] Runtime detection for BIKE (see https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/pull/1030#issuecomment-877292940)
~- [ ] Runtime detection for qTesla~
- [ ] Runtime detection for Picnic
- [x] Runtime detection for AES

comment.body:
If we close this without moving SIKE and Picnic to the same level, I'd suggest to explicitly document that limitation in the (runtime-) support of those algorithms: They'll always run slower than they could when `OQS_DIST_BUILD` is set (e.g., in profiling and docker images). We could add a sentence [here](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/wiki/Customizing-liboqs#OQS_DIST_BUILD): Something like 

> Note that Picnic and SIKE do not support this flag and this will always run with non-optimized code if setting OQS_DIST_BUILD.

issue.title: Collecting per-build environment algorithm failures
issue.body:
In support of #892 this is to document build failures by algorithm and build environment.

Using our CI tests, downstream integrations and manual tests supporting [the wiki build instructions](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/wiki/Platform-specific-notes-for-building-liboqs), all algorithms not listed below should be assumed to build and work OK on
- Ubuntu, Debian, Alpine x86_64 using gcc 7, gcc 8 and clang 9
- MacOS using XCode 11.3
- Windows using MSVC19, cygwin (gcc 9 and 10)
- ARM: 64, hf

Failures:
BIKE: fails to build completely under MSVC, thousands of errors, e.g.,
![grafik](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/57787676/118084839-a8623300-b3c1-11eb-8b14-c636b7ece5d3.png)

BIKE: fails also under cygwin (less dramatic), e.g.
```
[22/1510] Building ASM object src/kem/.../bike1_l1_fo.dir/additional/gf_mul.S.o
FAILED: src/kem/bike/CMakeFiles/bike1_l1_fo.dir/additional/gf_mul.S.o
/usr/bin/cc -DAVX2 -DFUNC_PREFIX=OQS_KEM_bike1_l1_fo -DLEVEL=1 -Iinclude -I/usr/include -fPIC -march=native -Werror -Wall -Wextra -Wpedantic -Wstrict-prototypes -Wshadow -Wformat=2 -Wfloat-equal -Wwrite-strings -O3 -fomit-frame-pointer -fdata-sections -ffunction-sections -Wl,--gc-sections -Wno-maybe-uninitialized -mavx2 -include /home/Administrator/git/liboqs/src/kem/bike/functions_renaming.h -MD -MT src/kem/bike/CMakeFiles/bike1_l1_fo.dir/additional/gf_mul.S.o -MF src/kem/bike/CMakeFiles/bike1_l1_fo.dir/additional/gf_mul.S.o.d -o src/kem/bike/CMakeFiles/bike1_l1_fo.dir/additional/gf_mul.S.o -c ../src/kem/bike/additional/gf_mul.S
../src/kem/bike/additional/gf_mul.S: Assembler messages:
../src/kem/bike/additional/gf_mul.S:70: Error: unknown pseudo-op: `.hidden'
../src/kem/bike/additional/gf_mul.S:71: Warning: .type pseudo-op used outside of .def/.endef: ignored.
../src/kem/bike/additional/gf_mul.S:71: Error: junk at end of line, first unrecognized character is `O'
../src/kem/bike/additional/gf_mul.S:130: Warning: .size pseudo-op used outside of .def/.endef: ignored.
../src/kem/bike/additional/gf_mul.S:130: Error: junk at end of line, first unrecognized character is `O'
../src/kem/bike/additional/gf_mul.S:187: Error: unknown pseudo-op: `.hidden'
../src/kem/bike/additional/gf_mul.S:188: Warning: .type pseudo-op used outside of .def/.endef: ignored.
../src/kem/bike/additional/gf_mul.S:188: Error: junk at end of line, first unrecognized character is `O'
../src/kem/bike/additional/gf_mul.S:232: Warning: .size pseudo-op used outside of .def/.endef: ignored.
../src/kem/bike/additional/gf_mul.S:232: Error: junk at end of line, first unrecognized character is `O'
../src/kem/bike/additional/gf_mul.S:283: Error: unknown pseudo-op: `.hidden'
../src/kem/bike/additional/gf_mul.S:284: Warning: .type pseudo-op used outside of .def/.endef: ignored.
../src/kem/bike/additional/gf_mul.S:284: Error: junk at end of line, first unrecognized character is `O'
../src/kem/bike/additional/gf_mul.S:315: Warning: .size pseudo-op used outside of .def/.endef: ignored.
../src/kem/bike/additional/gf_mul.S:315: Error: junk at end of line, first unrecognized character is `O'
```

Picnic: Fails under cygwin; probably unintended overload of system defines, e.g.:
```
/usr/bin/cc -DOQS -DPICNIC_STATIC -DWITH_KKW -DWITH_LOWMC_128_128_20 -DWITH_LOWMC_129_129_4 -DWITH_LOWMC_192_192_30 -DWITH_LOWMC_192_192_4 -DWITH_LOWMC_255_255_4 -DWITH_LOWMC_256_256_38 -DWITH_OPT -DWITH_SSE2 -DWITH_UNRUH -DWITH_ZKBPP -Iinclude -I../src/sig/picnic/external -fvisibility=hidden -march=native -Werror -Wall -Wextra -Wpedantic -Wstrict-prototypes -Wshadow -Wformat=2 -Wfloat-equal -Wwrite-strings -O3 -fomit-frame-pointer -fdata-sections -ffunction-sections -Wl,--gc-sections -Wno-maybe-uninitialized -Wno-missing-braces -std=gnu11 -MD -MT src/sig/picnic/CMakeFiles/picnic.dir/external/io.c.o -MF src/sig/picnic/CMakeFiles/picnic.dir/external/io.c.o.d -o src/sig/picnic/CMakeFiles/picnic.dir/external/io.c.o -c ../src/sig/picnic/external/io.c
In file included from ../src/sig/picnic/external/compat.h:62,
                 from ../src/sig/picnic/external/io.c:17:
../src/sig/picnic/external/endian_compat.h:151: error: "htobe16" redefined [-Werror]
  151 | #define htobe16(x) bswap16((x))
      |
In file included from /usr/include/machine/types.h:19,
                 from /usr/include/sys/types.h:224,
                 from /usr/include/stdio.h:61,
                 from ../src/sig/picnic/external/io.h:14,
                 from ../src/sig/picnic/external/io.c:14:
/usr/include/endian.h:42: note: this is the location of the previous definition
   42 | #define htobe16(x) __bswap_16(x)
      |
In file included from ../src/sig/picnic/external/compat.h:62,
                 from ../src/sig/picnic/external/io.c:17:
../src/sig/picnic/external/endian_compat.h:152: error: "htole16" redefined [-Werror]
  152 | #define htole16(x) ((uint16_t)(x))
      |
In file included from /usr/include/machine/types.h:19,
                 from /usr/include/sys/types.h:224,
                 from /usr/include/stdio.h:61,
                 from ../src/sig/picnic/external/io.h:14,
                 from ../src/sig/picnic/external/io.c:14:
/usr/include/endian.h:50: note: this is the location of the previous definition
   50 | #define htole16(x) (x)
      |
In file included from ../src/sig/picnic/external/compat.h:62,
                 from ../src/sig/picnic/external/io.c:17:
../src/sig/picnic/external/endian_compat.h:153: error: "be16toh" redefined [-Werror]
  153 | #define be16toh(x) bswap16((x))
      |
In file included from /usr/include/machine/types.h:19,
                 from /usr/include/sys/types.h:224,
                 from /usr/include/stdio.h:61,
                 from ../src/sig/picnic/external/io.h:14,
                 from ../src/sig/picnic/external/io.c:14:
/usr/include/endian.h:46: note: this is the location of the previous definition
   46 | #define be16toh(x) __bswap_16(x)
      |
In file included from ../src/sig/picnic/external/compat.h:62,
                 from ../src/sig/picnic/external/io.c:17:
../src/sig/picnic/external/endian_compat.h:154: error: "le16toh" redefined [-Werror]
  154 | #define le16toh(x) ((uint16_t)(x))
```

Question now: How to proceed?  Widen the matrix/check more environments (gcc 9, 10 on Linux; M1 on OSX; msys2/mingw in Win)? Fix these (e.g., could #887 make BIKE be usable on Windows)? "Just" document in #892? What else?

Feedback solicited @jschanck @dstebila @christianpaquin @xvzcf

comment.body: #887 should already have closed this. The datasheets further document things well.

issue.title: undefined references to `OQS_KEM_frodokem_640_shake_keypair`
issue.body:
I am compiling the liboqs using the waf/wscript building system for the `ave32-gcc` compiler.
Now I encounter the following errors during linking:

```
[218/220] Linking build/nanomind.elf
lib/liboqs/src/kem/frodokem/kem_frodokem640shake.c.2.o: In function `OQS_KEM_frodokem_640_shake_new':
/home/simon/workspace/OBC-devboard-1.2.1/build/../lib/liboqs/src/kem/frodokem/kem_frodokem640shake.c:9: undefined reference to `OQS_KEM_frodokem_640_shake_keypair'
/home/simon/workspace/OBC-devboard-1.2.1/build/../lib/liboqs/src/kem/frodokem/kem_frodokem640shake.c:9: undefined reference to `OQS_KEM_frodokem_640_shake_encaps'
/home/simon/workspace/OBC-devboard-1.2.1/build/../lib/liboqs/src/kem/frodokem/kem_frodokem640shake.c:9: undefined reference to `OQS_KEM_frodokem_640_shake_decaps'
```

I tried to search for the source file of the definition but I cannot find the implementation of these 3 funcitons.
A [search in the github repo](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/search?q=OQS_KEM_frodokem_976_aes_encaps) also only shows the 3 results.

```bash
> pwd
/home/simon/workspace/liboqs
> grep -rn . -e 'OQS_KEM_frodokem_976_aes_encaps'
./src/kem/frodokem/external/frodo976aes_params.h:29:#define crypto_kem_enc                OQS_KEM_frodokem_976_aes_encaps
./src/kem/frodokem/kem_frodokem.h:37:OQS_API OQS_STATUS OQS_KEM_frodokem_976_aes_encaps(uint8_t *ciphertext, uint8_t *shared_secret, const uint8_t *public_key);
./src/kem/frodokem/kem_frodokem976aes.c:27:	kem->encaps = OQS_KEM_frodokem_976_aes_encaps;
Binary file ./build/lib/liboqs.a matches
./build/include/oqs/kem_frodokem.h:37:OQS_API OQS_STATUS OQS_KEM_frodokem_976_aes_encaps(uint8_t *ciphertext, uint8_t *shared_secret, const uint8_t *public_key);
Binary file ./build/src/kem/frodokem/CMakeFiles/frodokem.dir/kem_frodokem976aes.c.o matches
Binary file ./build/src/kem/frodokem/CMakeFiles/frodokem.dir/external/frodo976aes.c.o matches
Binary file ./build/tests/test_kem_mem matches
Binary file ./build/tests/kat_kem matches
Binary file ./build/tests/test_kem matches
Binary file ./build/tests/speed_kem matches
Binary file ./build/tests/example_kem matches
```

Where are those functions implemented?
The binary files in the build directory are of no use to me since I use a different compiler.

comment.body:
How important is the C11 requirement?
Unfortunately the latest `avr32-gcc` (3.4.2) only supports up to C99.
If delete the `set(CMAKE_C_STANDARD_REQUIRED ON)`, the build process obviously fails with:

```
cc1: error: unrecognized command line option "-Wpedantic"
```


I tried to search for the source file of the definition but I cannot find the implementation of these 3 funcitons.

```bash
> pwd
/home/simon/workspace/liboqs

./build/include/oqs/kem_frodokem.h:37:OQS_API OQS_STATUS OQS_KEM_frodokem_976_aes_encaps(uint8_t *ciphertext, uint8_t *shared_secret, const uint8_t *public_key);

Binary file ./build/tests/test_kem_mem matches
Binary file ./build/tests/kat_kem matches

Binary file ./build/tests/speed_kem matches
Binary file ./build/tests/example_kem matches
```

Where are those functions implemented?
The binary files in the build directory are of no use to me since I use a different compiler.

comment.body:
> How important is the C11 requirement?

I'd say "rather relevant for reasonably portable code". But then again, if you have a(n old) compiler for an old architecture, what speaks against conditionally (upon compiler/architecture) setting `cmake` property C_STANDARD suitably (`99` for avr32, `11` for everything else) or --less desirable-- switching off `CMAKE_C_STANDARD_REQUIRED` *only* for avr32?

comment.body:
Yes, for now I am digging through the error messages while having `CMAKE_C_STANDARD_REQUIRED=OFF`. Turns out, there are many more problems.

First there is the unsupported `#pragma`s
```
../src/kem/bike/additional_r3/types.h:25: error: #pragma pack(push[, id], <n>) is not supported on this target
../src/kem/bike/additional_r3/types.h:120: error: #pragma pack(pop[, id], <n>) is not supported on this target
```
which means, I would also have to wire more preprocessor directives into all these source files and not just the CMake scripts.

And then the endless errors which really should not happen
(meaning, something is really wrong with perhaps the included files..)
```bash
simon@vbvox ~/w/l/build (avr32-build)> ninja
[1/1066] Building C object src/kem/sike/CMakeFiles/sike.dir/external/P751/P751.c.obj
FAILED: src/kem/sike/CMakeFiles/sike.dir/external/P751/P751.c.obj 
/usr/local/avr32/bin/avr32-gcc -DCOMPILER_GCC -D_AVR32_ -D_GENERIC_ -Iinclude -fPIC -fvisibility=hidden   -Werror -Wall -Wextra -Wstrict-prototypes -Wshadow -Wformat=2 -Wfloat-equal -Wwrite-strings -O3 -fomit-frame-pointer -fdata-sections -ffunction-sections -Wl,--gc-sections -Wno-unused-function -Wno-error -std=gnu99 -MD -MT src/kem/sike/CMakeFiles/sike.dir/external/P751/P751.c.obj -MF src/kem/sike/CMakeFiles/sike.dir/external/P751/P751.c.obj.d -o src/kem/sike/CMakeFiles/sike.dir/external/P751/P751.c.obj   -c ../src/kem/sike/external/P751/P751.c
In file included from ../src/kem/sike/external/P751/P751.c:10:
../src/kem/sike/external/P751/P751_internal.h:98: error: 'NWORDS_FIELD' undeclared here (not in a function)
../src/kem/sike/external/P751/P751_internal.h:100: warning: type defaults to 'int' in declaration of 'f2elm_t'
In file included from ../src/kem/sike/external/P751/P751.c:164:
../src/kem/sike/external/P751/generic/fp_generic.c: In function 'rdc_mont':
../src/kem/sike/external/P751/generic/fp_generic.c:193: error: 'p751_ZERO_WORDS' undeclared (first use in this function)
```

issue.title: Use Github Actions for some CI
issue.body:
<!-- Please give a brief explanation of the purpose of this pull request. -->
In hopes of partially alleviating pressure on our CircleCI quota as per #1025, this PR switches some jobs to use Github Actions rather than CircleCI.  In particular, I've started off with more "standalone" type jobs, which include:
- alpine (2 jobs - with OpenSSL and without)
- address sanitizer (1 job) (currently disabled until #1067 lands)
- ARM emulation jobs (1 job - armhf)

Nothing stops us from moving other jobs over as well, such as the main Ubuntu x86_64 and i386 jobs, or the macOS jobs, or even the Windows jobs.  But I wanted to get initial feedback and discussion of strategy.  This currently doesn't affect triggering of downstream jobs (when a merge to main happens) or Travis/Appveyor (except for filtering branches of the form `ghactionsonly-*` from being run on those other CI platforms, allowing us to test just this one CI system).

Although the build shows as red, if the only failure is CircleCI, then that's due to there being no jobs that are meant to be run on CircleCI due to the `ghactionsonly-*` filtering currently going on.  That problem should not be present on other branches.

comment.body:
> Thanks @dstebila for setting this up/giving this a try! This seems to be a reasonable way out of our (C)CI timing problems -- assuming GHActions doesn't impose similar limitations once more tests are running there at the same time: Does anyone know about that -- short of trying it by moving over all jobs?

PQClean does much of its testing on Github Actions, with many more jobs than we have, and does not seem to encounter usage limitations.

> Judging from the code and run logs, the approach looks good to me: Same baseline containers, very similar test code, better runtime.
> On the negative side, this adds to our CI "zoo". 

Given that the jobs are very similar, I feel like this isn't too much of a burden. Getting started with a new CI provider is a cost, but now that I've done that hopefully it's not too much of a burden to keep it going.  

> Or is the idea to move _everything_ over to GHActions? If so (my personal preference to not deal with different CI system's quirks), I'd think we'd need to add `ssh(d)` support to our CI containers and do something similar to [this](https://github.com/marketplace?category=testing&type=actions&query=ssh+) to enable SSH access to debug problems with CI.

I do not intend at this point to move everything over to Github Actions.  I just wanted to reduce some of the CI backlog we'd been encountering due to over-reliance on the free part of CircleCI.  And Github Actions has a few drawbacks compared to CircleCI -- including no native support for SSH access and no fancy test results reporting.

issue.title: Use Github Actions for some CI
issue.body:
<!-- Please give a brief explanation of the purpose of this pull request. -->
In hopes of partially alleviating pressure on our CircleCI quota as per #1025, this PR switches some jobs to use Github Actions rather than CircleCI.  In particular, I've started off with more "standalone" type jobs, which include:
- alpine (2 jobs - with OpenSSL and without)
- address sanitizer (1 job) (currently disabled until #1067 lands)
- ARM emulation jobs (1 job - armhf)

Nothing stops us from moving other jobs over as well, such as the main Ubuntu x86_64 and i386 jobs, or the macOS jobs, or even the Windows jobs.  But I wanted to get initial feedback and discussion of strategy.  This currently doesn't affect triggering of downstream jobs (when a merge to main happens) or Travis/Appveyor (except for filtering branches of the form `ghactionsonly-*` from being run on those other CI platforms, allowing us to test just this one CI system).

Although the build shows as red, if the only failure is CircleCI, then that's due to there being no jobs that are meant to be run on CircleCI due to the `ghactionsonly-*` filtering currently going on.  That problem should not be present on other branches.

comment.body:
> After digging some more, I'm now a bit concerned reading [this](https://docs.github.com/en/billing/managing-billing-for-github-actions/about-billing-for-github-actions#minute-multipliers) considering moving over OSX and Windows jobs: This way, we could easily exceed [these quotas/limits](https://docs.github.com/en/billing/managing-billing-for-github-actions/about-billing-for-github-actions#included-storage-and-minutes) bringing us to where we stand right now: Up against a "pay wall". I've got the nagging feeling now that we have to decide whether we want to pay CircleCI (Amazon?) or Github (Microsoft?), to keep our level of testing if we want to avoid the "CI zoo". If not, we pay with our time (juggling/staying within the quotas of different CI systems).

Since we're a public repository, we don't have a quota limit and pay for anything, and in principle the 10x / 2x cost for macOS and Windows jobs doesn't affect us.

issue.title: automate setting security/NIST levels in generate.py using liboqs input
issue.body:
Fixes #315 

This new logic could also be used to completely do away with fields "[bits_]security" in `generate.yml` (as it can deduce them from `liboqs`' `claimed_nist_level`. What'd you think @dstebila @xvzcf ?

comment.body:
> > reading the NIST levels from the liboqs algorithm datasheets.
> 
> Agreed, it does. However, this does not ascertain that the NIST levels in `liboqs` and `oqs-openssl` do match, as the former are not read from the datasheets. Hence, this code does not fix #315. It would, of course, if similar NIST level "doc->src ascertainment" would be added to `liboqs`: Is that your intention?

Do you mean that there's no check that the security levels in liboqs/docs/algorithms/*/*.yml and e.g. liboqs/src/kem/sike/kem_sike.c (and all other KEMs and SIGs) match?  If so, I agree that's something that should be checked, but should be done in liboqs.  

If you mean that there's something else here in OQS-OpenSSL where matching security levels are not checked, then I'm not sure what you're referring to.  I notice that in openssl/oqs-template/generate.yml there are (for KEMs) `extra_nids` hybrid groups that mix with e.g. x25519 that could be checked, and (for SIGs) the `mix_with` hybrid combinations that could be checked.

comment.body:
>  If so, I agree that's something that should be checked, but should be done in liboqs.

Yes, that's what I mean. And agreed, it's something that needs to be done in `liboqs`. Unsure where, though... New script (checking doc/src "agreement")?

I've created https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/pull/1070 to resolve that. 

So I think there's nothing left to do on this PR; if you're happy with it, please approve the review and we can merge.

issue.title: undefined references to `OQS_KEM_frodokem_640_shake_keypair`
issue.body:
I am compiling the liboqs using the waf/wscript building system for the `ave32-gcc` compiler.
Now I encounter the following errors during linking:

```
[218/220] Linking build/nanomind.elf
lib/liboqs/src/kem/frodokem/kem_frodokem640shake.c.2.o: In function `OQS_KEM_frodokem_640_shake_new':
/home/simon/workspace/OBC-devboard-1.2.1/build/../lib/liboqs/src/kem/frodokem/kem_frodokem640shake.c:9: undefined reference to `OQS_KEM_frodokem_640_shake_keypair'
/home/simon/workspace/OBC-devboard-1.2.1/build/../lib/liboqs/src/kem/frodokem/kem_frodokem640shake.c:9: undefined reference to `OQS_KEM_frodokem_640_shake_encaps'
/home/simon/workspace/OBC-devboard-1.2.1/build/../lib/liboqs/src/kem/frodokem/kem_frodokem640shake.c:9: undefined reference to `OQS_KEM_frodokem_640_shake_decaps'
```

I tried to search for the source file of the definition but I cannot find the implementation of these 3 funcitons.
A [search in the github repo](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/search?q=OQS_KEM_frodokem_976_aes_encaps) also only shows the 3 results.

```bash
> pwd
/home/simon/workspace/liboqs
> grep -rn . -e 'OQS_KEM_frodokem_976_aes_encaps'
./src/kem/frodokem/external/frodo976aes_params.h:29:#define crypto_kem_enc                OQS_KEM_frodokem_976_aes_encaps
./src/kem/frodokem/kem_frodokem.h:37:OQS_API OQS_STATUS OQS_KEM_frodokem_976_aes_encaps(uint8_t *ciphertext, uint8_t *shared_secret, const uint8_t *public_key);
./src/kem/frodokem/kem_frodokem976aes.c:27:	kem->encaps = OQS_KEM_frodokem_976_aes_encaps;
Binary file ./build/lib/liboqs.a matches
./build/include/oqs/kem_frodokem.h:37:OQS_API OQS_STATUS OQS_KEM_frodokem_976_aes_encaps(uint8_t *ciphertext, uint8_t *shared_secret, const uint8_t *public_key);
Binary file ./build/src/kem/frodokem/CMakeFiles/frodokem.dir/kem_frodokem976aes.c.o matches
Binary file ./build/src/kem/frodokem/CMakeFiles/frodokem.dir/external/frodo976aes.c.o matches
Binary file ./build/tests/test_kem_mem matches
Binary file ./build/tests/kat_kem matches
Binary file ./build/tests/test_kem matches
Binary file ./build/tests/speed_kem matches
Binary file ./build/tests/example_kem matches
```

Where are those functions implemented?
The binary files in the build directory are of no use to me since I use a different compiler.

comment.body: I don't have a good sense of how far the present code is from being C99 compliant. I know that some code in liboqs does use alignment-related features (e.g., `aligned_alloc`) which I believe is new to C11, which would make it problematic to revert everything to C99.

issue.title: Add test suite comparing parameters in C with parameters in YML
issue.body:
<!-- Please give a brief explanation of the purpose of this pull request. -->
Based on discussion in https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssl/pull/316#issuecomment-893521915.

comment.body:
> The Unicode issue in CI (probably regarding some authors names) probably needs addressing before a merge, though.

Fixing the Unicode issue now. As for the other platforms where it fails due to lack of the Python YAML package being installed, I'll just skip this test on those platforms; it isn't critical this test is executed on all platforms.

issue.title: Use Github Actions for some CI
issue.body:
<!-- Please give a brief explanation of the purpose of this pull request. -->
In hopes of partially alleviating pressure on our CircleCI quota as per #1025, this PR switches some jobs to use Github Actions rather than CircleCI.  In particular, I've started off with more "standalone" type jobs, which include:
- alpine (2 jobs - with OpenSSL and without)
- address sanitizer (1 job) (currently disabled until #1067 lands)
- ARM emulation jobs (1 job - armhf)

Nothing stops us from moving other jobs over as well, such as the main Ubuntu x86_64 and i386 jobs, or the macOS jobs, or even the Windows jobs.  But I wanted to get initial feedback and discussion of strategy.  This currently doesn't affect triggering of downstream jobs (when a merge to main happens) or Travis/Appveyor (except for filtering branches of the form `ghactionsonly-*` from being run on those other CI platforms, allowing us to test just this one CI system).

Although the build shows as red, if the only failure is CircleCI, then that's due to there being no jobs that are meant to be run on CircleCI due to the `ghactionsonly-*` filtering currently going on.  That problem should not be present on other branches.

comment.body:
> Since we're a public repository, we don't have a quota limit and pay for anything

That sounds too good to be true: When reading "[GitHub Actions usage is free for both public repositories and self-hosted runners.](https://docs.github.com/en/billing/managing-billing-for-github-actions/about-billing-for-github-actions)" I thought that would mean we're in the "Github Free" category -- which does have a monthly quota. But if all jobs indeed are free, so much the better.
